description: From Middle English retret, from Old French retrait or retret, from Latin retractus, from retraho. Doublet of retract.

entries.meaning: The act of pulling back or withdrawing, as from something dangerous, or unpleasant.
The act of reversing direction and receding from a forward position.
A peaceful, quiet place affording privacy or security.
examples: ... he built his son a house of pleasure, on purpose to keep him out of harm's way; and spared neither art nor cost to make it a delicious retreat.

entries.meaning: (rare and obsolete, euphemistic) A peaceful, quiet place in which to urinate and defecate: an outhouse; a lavatory.
A period of retirement, seclusion, or solitude.
examples: We both need a week retreat after those two stressful years working in the city.

entries.meaning: A period of meditation, prayer or study.
Withdrawal by military force from a dangerous position or from enemy attack.
examples: The general opted for a swift retreat because he saw his troops were vastly outnumbered.

entries.meaning: A signal for a military withdrawal.
A bugle call or drumbeat signaling the lowering of the flag at sunset, as on a military base.
A military ceremony to lower the flag.
(chess) The move of a piece from a threatened position.

verbs.description: retreat (third-person singular simple present retreats, present participle retreating, simple past and past participle retreated) (intransitive)

definitionGroups.group: To withdraw from a position, go back.

examples: The general refused to order his soldiers to retreat, despite being vastly outnumbered.

entries.meaning: (of a glacier) To shrink back due to generally warmer temperatures.

verbs.description: retreat (third-person singular simple present retreats, present participle retreating, simple past and past participle retreated)
